entry.title: System copy for convergent charging
entry.content:
What is convergent charging?

SAP Convergent Charging is a powerful rating and pricing solution designed for high-volume processing in service industries, particularly within the SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) ecosystem.

SAP Convergent Charging serves as a critical component that handles the rating and pricing aspects of order-to-cash scenarios. The system processes consumption data through several key steps :

  1. Receiving consumption items from Convergent Mediation as input
  2. Calculating corresponding usage fees for these consumption items
  3. Generating billable items that are loaded into Convergent Invoicing for billing purposes

Assumptions

1. Target convergent charging (CC) environment is already available.

2. Source and Target are on the same versions

3. Database type is same on source and target

Now , lets go through the pre-requisites , restore and post steps of convergent charging system copy.

Pre-requisites

1. Parameter export on source and target

The parameters would be later required for comparison

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<Instance number>/script

 Command - ./config.sh configuration export <directory>/parameters.xml all

2. Jstart parameters of source for all instances

The parameters would be later required for comparison

These are located in /usr/sap/<SID>/CC<Instance name><Instance number>/config.

Filename – jstart.config

3. License Export on Target

License on the target would be overwritten. Hence take a backup which would be later restored.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh license export exports/license.txt

4. Instance Map export on Target

Instance map would also be overwritten , this would be later imported in post steps.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh instancemap export exports/instance_map.txt

5. Export Jco destinations on Target

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh jcodestination export S/4 exports/jco_s4hana.txt

6. ERP reference system check

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh erpreferencesystem getJCoDestination

7. Export target database tables

The following tables should be exported from the target system in order to use them if needed. The export can be used to overwrite the configuration coming with the restore of the source system.

• LICENSE,

• VERSION,

• CONFIGURATION,

• INSTANCE_CONFIGURATION,

• INSTANCE_MAP,

• KEY_STORE,

• INSTANCE_KEY_STORE,

• INSTANCE_CERT_STORE,

• CERT_STORE,

8. Take a backup of target database before restore

9. Get the super user passwords of source 

Restore 

Copy the backup taken on source to target. Restore it on the target database using available database tools

Once the backup is restored , validate the super user passwords on target

Post Steps

1. If the schema of target differs from source , update the schema name and password

Update database user and password in DEFAULT profile and boot config files.

Directory - /sapmnt/<SID>/profile

File – DEFAULT.PFL

Update database.login field with new schema name and database.password field with new password

Directory - /sapmnt/<SID>/profile/boot

File – boot.config

Update SQLHELPER_LOGIN  field with new schema name and SQLHELPER.PASSWORD field with new password

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/config

File – boot.config

Update SQLHELPER_LOGIN  field with new schema name and SQLHELPER.PASSWORD field with new password

2. Reset Admin User credentials

Execute below SQL statements from schema user. Refer SAP note 2699499.

 

DELETE FROM USER_PASSWORD WHERE USER_OID = 1;
DELETE FROM USER_RIGHT WHERE USER_OID = 1;
DELETE FROM HCI_USER WHERE OID = 1;
INSERT INTO HCI_USER (OID, LOGIN_ID, PASSWORD, PASSWORD_CHANGE_DATE,
FAILED_LOGIN_COUNT, LOCKED, IS_HUMAN, CHANGE_PASSWORD)
VALUES (1, 'admin', '6989cd27e1ebb4d8f266d5c09469989f1caae07', CURRENT_DATE, 0, 0, 1, 0);
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'admin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'useradmin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'csr');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'marketing');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'bartadmin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'connectoradmin');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'processmanager');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'remotesupport');
INSERT INTO USER_RIGHT(USER_OID, USER_RIGHT) VALUES (1, 'messagechargingclient');

 

3. Import License

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command – ./setup.sh license import exports/license.txt

 

4. Update jcodestination 

 

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command –  ./setup.sh jcodestination list

 

As seen from above screenshot , there are 2 destinations defined. These need to be adjusted. First step is to export them locally , edit as per target and import them again.

To export, use below commands

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command –   ./setup.sh jcodestination export <ERP_JCO_NAME> <ERP_JCO_NAME>.txt

Adjust the hostname in txt file and import using below command.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./setup.sh jcodestination import ERP <ERP_JCO_NAME> <ERP_JCO_NAME>.txt

Similarly , repeat for CRM destination as well.

 

5. Parameter update

Compare the parameters from source to target in parameters.xml file and change them. Special care to be taken for SQLHELPER_LOGIN which specifies the schema name and SQLHELPER_PASSWORD for schema password. If the parameters are not updated correctly , system wont start. Once the parameters are updated , use below commands to import them.

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command - ./config.sh configuration import parameters.xml

6. Jstart Files

Compare jstart.config files for all the instances with source and update them.

7. Update instance map

Directory - /usr/sap/<SID>/CCD<INSTANCE NO>/script

Command –  ./setup.sh instancemap import exports/instance_map.txt -clean

8. Finally , start the system with sapcontrol command.

 

Common issues after system copy

1. Bulkloader wont start while starting the system

Check the bulkloader logs in /usr/sap/<SID>/CCB<Instance number>/work/log/. The password or host details might not be updated correctly. Export the jcodestinations and manually update the correct details and import. This should be followed by restart of complete system.

entry.title: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
“In the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.” – Albert Einstein

Handling large-volume data integration is something every integration specialist meets sooner or later. Recently, our team faced one of those “opportunities”—a requirement to transfer around 10 million records from a source system to a target application using SAP Integration Suite (IS) formerly called as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI).

At first glance, the mapping requirements were straightforward. But as always, the devil hides in the details: the pagination behavior of the OData V4 adapter, the Integration Suite processing limits, and unforeseen behavioral quirks pushed us through several attempts before landing on a robust solution.

This blog walks through:

  • What approaches we tried
  • Why they failed
  • What finally worked
  • Key learnings for anyone building high-volume integrations on SAP IS

Context: The Scenario

The source system exposed data through an OData V4 service. A key limitation we discovered early on:

  • Pagination is fully server-controlled in OData V4 adapter
  • Even if SAP IS is configured for a custom page size (e.g., 1,000 or 10,000), the adapter always respects the server-side limit
  • Example: If the server page size is 50,000, SAP IS will always retrieve chunks of 50,000 - nothing less

This limitation became the center of the problem.

Approach 1 — Standard OData V4 Adapter + Looping Process Call

(Expected to work… reality had other plans)

How it worked:

  • Used the OData V4 adapter as-is with server-side pagination
  • Used Looping Process Call to iterate through pages

What happened:

  • If the total data was below 50K, everything worked smoothly
  • Above 50K, the iFlow got stuck in Processing
  • No errors
  • No termination
  • Messages remained frozen for days

Example:

  • Server page size → 50K
  • Data set = 40K → Success
  • Data set = 150K → iFlow stalled indefinitely

Lesson: Looping + uncontrolled server pagination = unpredictable behavior.

Approach 2 — OData V4 Adapter + Custom Pagination Logic

(Better… but still not scalable enough)

This time we added:

  • Custom counter checks
  • Pagination logic in iFlow
  • Looping until full completion

Result:

  • Worked better than Approach 1
  • Successfully processed volumes under ~1 million records
  • Beyond that threshold → iFlow stuck again, still showing Processing but not progressing
  • No runtime error, no bottleneck in MPL — simply a silent stall

Lesson: The bottleneck was structural, not logical.

Approach 3 — Final Working Solution (and the hero of the story)

“Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.” — Leonardo da Vinci

Key idea:

Avoid OData V4 adapter entirely.

Use the Classic HTTP Adapter with explicit control over pagination (via top & skip).

This allowed us to fully control the data fetch size and execution flow.

Our Winning Architecture

Flow 1: Master Controller iFlow

  1. Call the source system via HTTP adapter
  2. Retrieve total record count
  3. Calculate the required number of batches
    • Batch size = server-side max (e.g., 50K)
  4. For each batch, create a message containing only the skip value
  5. Store skip values in Data Store

Example:

Total records = 1,000,000
Batch size = 50,000
Total batches = 20
Stored skip values = 0, 50000, 100000, ...


Flow 2: Worker iFlow

  1. Poll Data Store
  2. Read skip value
  3. Call API using HTTP adapter with parameters:
    $top=50000
    $skip=<value from datastore>
  4. Process the dataset
  5. Deliver to target system

The Big Win

This mechanism:

  • Gave us full control over pagination
  • Completely bypassed OData V4 limitations
  • Handled 10+ MILLION records without stalls
  • Achieved stable throughput
  • No permanent IFlow “Processing” states
  • No invisible bottlenecks

Lesson: If the adapter limits you, take control with HTTP.

Key Learnings

  • SAP Integration Suite is powerful and evolving, but very high-volume scenarios still expose adapter-level limitations
  • OData V4 Adapter may not be suitable for massive pagination-driven extractions in all cases
  • HTTP adapter with custom pagination is a reliable fallback
  • Sometimes the “classic” tool is the best tool

And yes—raising an SAP incident might eventually clarify the root cause, but business timelines forced us to engineer a workaround.

Conclusion

High-volume data integration is never trivial. The key is to experiment, observe system behavior, and design around limitations. Our final approach was not just functional—it was scalable, predictable, and production-proof.

If you’re dealing with similar large dataset transfers in SAP IS, this solution pattern might save you hours of troubleshooting.

Feedback Welcome

I’d love to hear your thoughts, improvements, or other patterns you’ve successfully used for large-volume integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite.

Thank you for reading!

I2Integration Solutions | A Startup

Connect in LinkedIn: I2Integrate

entry.title: Re: Packing instruction and determination by using refere...
entry.content:
Dear @ST24,

Yes in Public Cloud it’s normal that 0IBD packing instruction determination is evaluated on the delivery item product plus supplier/warehouse so a determination record maintained only for your reference material (ref-pallet1) will not be hit for an inbound delivery item whose product is WMTG12.

  • In the 3BR (Warehouse Inbound Processing) best-practice script, SAP explicitly notes that for 0IBD determination you can use only: Warehouse Number, Supplier, Material. That means there’s no standard key for reference material for packing in the delivered 0IBD determination in this scope/item
  • So the system will only find the packing instruction if you maintain a determination record with Material = WMTG12 (referencing the packing instruction you created on ref-pallet1). That’s exactly what you observed

 

  • The reference material for packing setup is mainly to reuse the same packing instruction master data across many products so you don’t create many packing instructions, but you still need determination records per product if your 0IBD condition access is product-based as in the standard cloud best practice
  • Some SAP docs/screens show reference material for packing as a possible field in determination records in general but your specific 0IBD setup in Public Cloud is effectively constrained to the product-based keys

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/fdae694b57b24c568e284e43a88d76d1.html

Summary:

  • Keep one packing instruction built on ref-pallet1
  • Maintain packing instruction determination for each product like WMTG12, all pointing to that same packing instruction. This is the expected/working approach per the cloud best-practice flow

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Credit check triggered again when delivery date is changed-Credit managment
entry.content:
Hello 

when a customer delivery date is changed a new credit approval request is generated.  This occurs even if the $ value of the order has not changed. Multiple credit approvals on an order should only be required if the value of the order has changed as approval has already been granted

entry.title: リースイン契約の税認識のタイミング調整 - パブクラ編
entry.content:
はじめに

日本の消費税認識タイミングとしては、リース資産の利用を開始したタイミングでリース料全額の消費税を認識する必要があります。ただ、スコープアイテム1T6でリース管理をする際に、普通に設定してしまうと、リース料支払いのタイミングで消費税が認識される動きとなってしまいます。

この税認識タイミングを調整するためのコンサルティングノートがリリースされています。
https://me.sap.com/notes/3547732
ただし、プライベート向けの記載となっており、パブリッククラウドの環境で実装しようとすると引っかかる部分があるため、差分についてこちらの記事に記載したいと思います。

検証にあたってはこちらのヘルプ文書を参考にしました。なぜか2502版にしか記述がなく、2508版には記述がないため、そのうち見れなくなってしまう予感がします。
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b8c08e0197454541a11f8d46ef1ab96e/58f24782ab9f45fa9b38d2f735b1bdb5.html?version=2502.500&locale=ja-JP

この記事は SAP Advent Calendar 2025 の12月3日分の記事として執筆しています

プライベートとの差分

1. 必要な条件タイプが事前定義されている

ノート記載の手順にはマニュアルでYM80、YM90というフロータイプと条件タイプを定義するステップがありますが、プライベートの場合はJT80、JT90という条件タイプが事前提供されており、追加設定は不要です。

2. 代替統制勘定への置き換えは契約マスタ登録時にマニュアル設定する必要がある

プライベートの場合、勘定シンボルのコンフィグで特殊仕訳コードを指定するか、BAdIで代入を実装することで未払金が別の統制勘定で計上されるように自動化しています。

パブクラの場合、該当の SSCUI 102120 置換: 勘定シンボル のコンフィグに特殊仕訳コードの列がなく、コンフィグでの解決ができません。また、代入用のBAdIもありません。

ここで詰んだ、と思ったのですが、上で紹介したヘルプ文書に記載のとおり、
新規契約登録時に、転記タブの「勘定設定値」項目に、代替統制勘定の値「TX」を設定することで解決します。

必要なコンフィグ

あくまで一例です。

SSCUI 150001 勘定コード追加

「支払われるリース料の合計金額（BS科目）」「支払われるリース料の合計金額の相手勘定（仕入先統制勘定）」の2勘定を追加する
ノートの添付ファイルを参考にした勘定テキスト案はそれぞれ「リース資産 消費税調整勘定（JP）」「未払金（RE 税調整・支払対象外）」など

SSCUI 102120 置換：勘定シンボル

S-CLEARINGTAX、S-TAXONROUに、「支払われるリース料の合計金額（BS科目）」の勘定コードを割り当て

SSCUI 102631 代替統制勘定

未払金科目に対して「支払われるリース料の合計金額の相手勘定（仕入先統制勘定）」を代替統制勘定として割当
勘定IDに「TX」を設定

おわりに

該当ノートの冒頭に

当ノートはコンサルティングノートです。 ご質問がある場合は、コンサルティングサービス (有償) をご利用ください。

と記載があったので、パブクラ向けの追記や更新を期待するのは難しそうだなーと思い、備忘のために記事にしました。
リース管理のスコープアイテムを利用している事例は少ないのかもしれませんが、ご参考になれば幸いです。

entry.title: TM Transportation Cockpit - Changing field attribute to editable?

entry.title: Re: Can the S4/HANA Public Cloud Updates overwrite my Cus...
entry.content:
Hello @AJ07 

Thank you for your question.

Your concerns are valid, in public cloud, you should not only use numeric primary keys when you create custom configuration entries. You can only do this if:

  • The range is officially reserved for your customer
  • Or if you have a confirmation from SAP that the range will not be used in the future for content deliveries.

For public cloud, it is safer to use Z or Y prefixes for custom keys, you should also avoid overlapping with numeric key space. Don’t forget to document your changes.

 

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The new purchase order picks up the price from the last purchase order.
entry.content:
Prerequisite.

  1. For the test, here I have created a material master with nothing special in it—just a normal material master with Basic data 1, Purchasing, Plant data 1 and account 1 view. 
  2. Supplier master with nothing special as well. 
  3. Configure SSCUI - Define Default Values for Buyers - 103909 as below. 

You can select A or B, or C, depending on business need. 

 

Step 1: Create a PO and mark the info update tick in the PO as below. Either ME21N or the Create Purchase Order app.

Save PO. and reopen PO to check the purchasing info record number in PO. 

Step 2: Open PIR in ME13 and validate prices. 

Here price will be zero if your PIR is created from the PO. 

In case if your PIR was created before, then go to ME12 in PIR.
Then, in the condition tab in PIR, remove the price from it and make it zero. So that condition will look like below in ME13. 
Don't worry about the price in the Purchasing view. 

Save PIR. 

Step 3: Run a background job to update the PIR price from purchasing documents.  (Job Program - RM06INP0).The 
Fiori app is - Schedule Update of Price for Purchasing Documents. For on-prem, it can be tested in SE38 as well. 
If it's cloud, use the Fiori app if its On-prem use the Program. Here i will use Fiori app.

Then decide on recurrence depending on how frequently you want the job to update PIRs with new prices from PO. 
If it's not very frequent, once a day is fine, but if it's too frequent, then maybe 10 min or so, depending on business need. 
I will use it once only, as I am just testing it. 


Select the right options that suits you and schedule a job. 

Then wait until the job is finished. 

Step 4: ME13 - Check if PIR net price updated in purchasing org data 1 view. 


So every time the job runs, it will check if a new document and new price is there, if new price idedntified then the system will update PIR for the combination. 

Step 5: Create a new PO and validate if the price is coming. 


Now for the test again, change the price to let's say 15 in the PO and check if the info update is active. 

Again background job will run if you have set a recurrence. Once the job runs, it will update the price.
Here, I will show in the backend how it updates in SE38 with the program RM06INP0 for understanding. 
Run the SE38 update program RM06INP0 and execute. 


Depending on the job selection criteria below, selection will happen. Here I am taking the material and supplier as well just for testing. 

Job will update the info record with the new price as shown, here I did in the front end only to understand, but in real time job will do it in background everytime job runs. 

Step 6: test again new PO in ME21N. 

New price will come again from last PO. 

Note that - If the background job is not executed between two PO creations, then the new price will not come, so select a background job run frequency appropriately.

This method only works if you do not use conditions and an access sequence. If you have value in conditions, this method will not work; in that case, you have to update the price manually for conditions in MEK2. 

Steps summary 

  1. PIR must be without condition.
  2. Mark PO with info update tick.
  3. Run job to update PIR prices - RM06INP0  or  Fiori - Schedule Update of Price for Purchasing Documents.
  4. Check the new price in ME13.
  5. Create a new PO and test.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Joule - Performance&Goals Agent Activation
entry.content:
Hi AI and Joule enthusiasts,

I’m sure you’ve been following the release updates and saw the H2 highlights on agentic AI for SuccessFactors.

Joule in SuccessFactors now supports its first agent for Performance and Goals - designed to help managers prepare for employee performance reviews.

For more details on the agent, please see: Performance and Goals Agent

 

If you are looking for the implementation steps you are very welcome to read the rest of the blog because I like to share the steps to get the agent activated and how you can test / trigger the agent.

 

Pre-Requisites for Agent Activation:

- Licenses: AI Units

- Joule for SuccessFactors is activated

 

Recommendation for PM/GM Agent Usage:

To maximize the effectiveness of the Performance and Goals Agent, we strongly recommend enabling one or more of the following modules: Performance Management, Goal Management, and Continuous Performance Management. This allows the agent to access relevant data from direct reports and provide more valuable analyses and actionable insights.

 

Activation Steps:

1. Activate the Agent in SuccessFactors:

  • Login to your SuccessFactors System
  • go to Admin Center  -> AI Services Administration ->  enable the Performance & Goals Agent

The Agent is currently marked as Base AI because we run a promotion phase (planned until Mai 2026). Please check the license model starting in April/Mail.

2. Assign Permissions to Manager: 

  • Login to your SuccessFactors System
  • assign permissions to your relevant permission roles: User Permissions ->  AI Access -> Performance & Goals Agent

The Agent is designed for Managers incl. access to employee details. Employees would not have access to the agents for there self.

3. Refresh CDM contents

  • login to your BTP Global Account
  • select the subaccount where Joule is implemented
  • login to the WorkZone Application assigned to the global account

 

  • Run a content channel refresh

  • after the successful refresh check the content manager -> a new Role should be added

Required activation Steps are done. Now you can wait that your regular jobs (SF - Refresh synchtetic Group Data and IPS - User/Group Synch to WorkZone) runs. If you want to test immediately you can also trigger this 2 jobs.

4. Trigger refresh synthetic group data job in SuccessFactors

  • login to your SuccessFactors System
  • go to Admin Center - > Scheduled Job Manager
  • Search for the refresh synthetic group data job and start the job 
    • If you have more then one job or not the explizite deepLinkActivatonPermission Job make sure you select the job that includes the deepLinkActivatonPermission as object

  • How to check: click on the Job to get the job details. As JobParameter "All" or "Common Data Model Content Deep-Link Access User Group" should be selected

 

 

5. Run IPS Job

After successful update of the Content Channel and a successful run of the SF job you can trigger your IPS Job.

  • login to your Cloud Identity Service System
  • Select Identity Provisioning -> Source System
  • Select the source system that feeds your Joule WorkZone System
  • Go to Jobs and run the Read or Re-Synch Job

6. Check the Group assignment

If all the jobs was successful users with Agent permissions should receive a new group in WorkZone. If you want to check this do the following:

  • login to your BTP Global Account
  • select the subaccount where Joule is implemented
  • login to the WorkZone Application assigned to the global account
  • select Settings -> Identity Provisioning
  • search for the global user id of a relevant manager

 

  • check if the Role is assigned  (the ID 8074 was created in my demo system, please search for your relevant id from step 3)

 

7. Test the agent

  • login to SuccessFactors as a manager
  • open Joule
  • trigger the Agent (the agent collects a lot of data and prepares details for you - be patient it will take a while)

 

Some sample prompts for working with the agent:

  • trigger the agent: Please help me to prepare my performance review meeting with <Employees Name>
  • some ideas you can ask the agent:
    • can you show me some more details on the received feedbacks?  [if continuous feedback is activated and used]
    • can you create a summary of the current existing performance forms?
    • can you summarize the goals and the status of achievement?

 

Have fun with testing.

 

Let us know in the comments what your favorite prompts during the usage are.

entry.title: Get Certified live sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - further relevant sessions
entry.content:
We offer several line-of-business specific Get Certified live session series for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, to support learners who will take the corresponding certification.  Each series focuses on the LOB content, but it is also important that learners have a solid understanding of the content from the course Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, in order to be completely prepared for the exam.

We highly recommend that you join the following live sessions (or watch the available recordings):

  • Foundational Concepts of Cloud Software and SAP Business Suite
  • Differentiating GROW and RISE with SAP for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Implementing with a Cloud Mindset for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public and Private Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Implementation Activities in a Nutshell
  • Building the Implementation Team & Managing Change during SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Projects
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3-System Landscape: Provisioning, Transports, & Release Upgrade
  • Setting Up the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Implementation Project in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Using SAP Central Business Configuration to Activate Content in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Starter System
  • Preparing for Fit-to-Standard Workshops in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Implementations
  • Conducting Fit-to-Standard Workshops in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Implementations
  • Using SAP Central Business Configuration to Activate Content in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Development System
  • Maintaining and Customizing Business Roles, Spaces, and Pages in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Customizing Fiori Applications with In-App Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Setting Up Integrations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Migrating Data with the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Using the Test Automation Tool in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

These sessions are recommended in addition to the LOB-specific sessions from the following Get Certified live session series:

Get Certified: SAP Certified Associate - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Management Accounting

Get Certified: Implementation Consultant - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Sourcing and Procurement 

Get Certified: Implementation Consultant - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Sales

entry.title: Important Communication to SAP Community Regarding Argentina e-Invoicing legal change and New Contin
entry.content:
Dear SAP users and community members,

SAP shares important information regarding the Argentinean tax authority General Resolution (GR) N° 5785/2025 and its implications for ERPs in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition variants.

Regulatory Summary

The Argentinean tax authority General Resolution N° 5785/2025 has established the CAEA method (Anticipated Electronic Authorization Code) as the primary contingency method option (for VAT registered taxpayers “Responsables Inscriptos”) for issuing Electronic Invoices under the CAE method.

How this LC impacts on Private and OP ERP Systems

Given that the CAEA method is not within the scope of SAP's standard localization for Argentina, for Private and OP ERP Systems, we inform you that the functionality for managing and implementing the CAEA method as a contingency will not be included in the scope of the Argentina localization for our ERP solutions in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. SAP understands that it has an extensive network of partner services within the SAP ecosystem.

On the other hand, please be informed that for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP plans to include this resolution since CAEA is included in the solution portfolio.

 It is also important to remark, that beside that CAEA option will not be covered by default, there are other contingency options that remain valid in SAP solutions, such as ON LINE and OFF LINE contingency (self-printers “autoimpresores”).

We recommend you review your internal contingency processes and, if necessary, explore complementary solutions that allow for the management of CAEA within the ecosystem of our on-premise ERPs, should this method be mandatory for your company to comply with GR 5785/2025.

For any additional questions regarding the scope of Argentina localization, please visit the SAP Help Portal, or use other established SAP communication channels.

 Thank you for your attention

SAP Globalization
Localization for Argentina

entry.title: RESULTLOOKUP/RESTRICT Not Accepting <=, >=, <, > Operators in SAC
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I believe I have encountered a bug in the SAP Analytics Cloud Formula Editor, both at the model level and within stories.

When creating a calculated measure using functions such as RESULTLOOKUP or RESTRICT, the second parameter (which defines the filter conditions) does not accept comparison operators such as:

  • <=

  • >=

  • <

  • >

Whenever I use one of these operators in the filter block, SAC returns the following error:

“Formula could not be computed: Function 'RESULTLOOKUP' expects parameter 2 to be a list of conditions joined with AND. Please complete or rewrite the formula.”

However, using = or != works fine.

 

Restrict with '='Restrict with '<='Restrict with '<' simple example

This limitation prevents me from implementing formulas that require range-based filters.
For example, I need to create a custom YTD calculation that retrieves values up to a specific period entered through a story parameter.

I also need additional measures that depend on parameters (e.g., current period, inception-to-date, etc.).
I found partial workarounds—such as creating restricted measures in the story using “less than or equal” input controls—but this quickly becomes inefficient. Each measure would require its own input control, meaning the customer would need to select the period multiple times, which is not a good user experience.

I also tried using an IF() statement inside a calculated measure, but then I am forced to display the required dimensions in the table, which is not acceptable from a reporting layout perspective.

My starting requirement is to build a report similar to the “Billing Extract for Invoice/Statement” available in:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud → via the app “Schedule Job for Billing”,

  • SAP S/4HANA on-premise → transaction code GJ12.

To replicate the logic in SAC, I need the ability to filter by period ranges using operators such as <=, which is currently failing in the Formula Editor.

Questions

  • Is this a known limitation or bug in SAC?

  • Is there a planned fix?

  • Is there an official workaround that avoids multiple input controls and avoids exposing dimensions in the table?

Thank you in advance for your help,

poklluka.

entry.title: Re: Attachments in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Dear @kaiwen_,

In Public Cloud when you add an attachment for example a PDF to a supplier invoice the binary file is stored in an attachment repository, while SAP stores the business-object linkage/metadata (who/when, BO key, filename/MIME type, repository reference, etc.). SAP’s docs explicitly describe the model as “content + metadata stored in the repository” and discuss repository options for attachment storage

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/9f2f1c9e067645418a20375211e1ea04.html

1. Standard repository

  • SAP documentation for Public Cloud states that the default repository for unstructured content is Document Service in SAP BTP
  • Practically the repository is not inside your Public Cloud database in the way business tables are it’s a separate content store managed/provisioned alongside your Public Cloud tenant

More details below:

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/fe051b8031274f919dae94150971c621.html

2. Third party repository

  • SAP supports integrating an external repository via CMIS and the customer-managed communication scenario SAP_COM_0597
  • SAP Integrating SAP Document Management guidance also references activating the needed communication arrangements including SAP_COM_0597 for SAP BTP Document Management connectivity

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/fe051b8031274f919dae94150971c621.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/03414f87d6e14dff9450e20e21632826.html

Attachment Service as the standard attachment handling layer used by Fiori apps:

  • It’s a reusable Fiori/UI component + backend services that lets apps upload, list, download, delete and in Advanced Attachment Service scenarios, things like check-in/check-out/versioning
  • It orchestrates storage it links the attachment to the business object and calls the repository typically via CMIS to store/retrieve the file content. SAP notes that the attachment service processing leverages the DMS and GOS frameworks and interacts with repositories via CMIS
  • It also enforces some technical constraints for example, SAP states a 100 MB per-file upload limit for Attachment Service usage in certain apps/scenarios

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/e7ff65b0c2c34652995745c9416edc5e.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/74fa9fbfe5ad47529fd8373bab397c36.html

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3591125

In CBC look at configuration activity below (103583) to see which repository is active.

 

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP Screen Personas 3.0 SP20: Enhancements to Flavor Management, BDT Support, and Adaptive Flavors
entry.content:
The latest update to SAP Screen Personas 3.0 with Service Pack 20 (SP20) introduces several powerful enhancements designed to make flavor creation, maintenance, and device-specific adaptation easier and more flexible than ever.
Below is a summary of the key improvements and how they benefit administrators, developers, and flavor builders.

1.  Copy a Flavor to Multiple Target Flavors

The former "Copy to Application ID" option has been enhanced and renamed to "Copy to Application ID or Flavor ID".
With this improvement, you can now copy a source flavor to target flavor. You can also you can apply the same source flavor to several target flavors in a single step, making mass flavor updates faster and more efficient.

When screens or transactions share similar layouts, you can reuse an existing flavor instead of starting from scratch.
For example: If you have a Display flavor and want to create a Change flavor, you can copy the Display flavor, adjust the fields that differ, and quickly finalize the Change version. This ensures consistency and significantly reduces development time.

Prerequisites

  • Personas Administrator role is required

  • Target flavors must already exist (either empty or with changes)

  • Source flavor must not contain an adaptive stack

For more details, refer to  Copy a Flavor to a Different Transaction in the documentation.
 
Additional  Options for BDT app flavors

BDT (Business Data Toolset) transactions often share identical detail screens but have different entry screens.
To support these scenarios,  an additional option has been introduced for BDT app flavors where the entry screen changes can be skipped during the copy process.
This allows flavor updates to be applied efficiently without impacting initial-screen behavior.

2. Adaptive Flavors for Custom Industrial Devices

Administrators can now define their own device list for adaptive flavor creation in SAP GUI for HTML and Slipstream Engine.

Until SP19, the device list was static and maintained exclusively by SAP. With SP20, administrators can register custom industrial devices used within their organization and specify attributes such as device width and pixel ratio. These values determine how an adaptive flavor is rendered for that specific device.  The newly added devices will be available to choose from list of devices while creating new adaptive flavors.

Additionally, in Slipstream Engine,the custom device created by the administrator becomes available in the Device Preview list, allowing designers to preview exactly how a flavor will appear on a custom company device.

Benefits

  • Enables greater flexibility in optimizing the user experience for rugged devices, handheld scanners, industrial tablets, and other specialized hardware.

  • Ensures that flavors are responsive and visually optimized for the intended device landscape.

  • Streamlines the design cycle and reduces trial-and-error.

For more information, see Devices.

3. BDT Mode Enabled by Default

With SP20, BDT Mode is now enabled by default, simplifying setup and configuration.

This means there is no need to manually set the ENABLE_BDT_MODE parameter in /PERSONAS/ADMIN when creating flavors for Business Data Toolset (BDT)–enabled transactions, such as Business Partner (BP) screens.

To support legacy flavors created without BDT mode enabled, a new parameter—DISABLE_BDT_MODE—has been introduced.

This ensures that administrators can preserve previous behavior and that legacy BDT flavors continue to function correctly after the SP20 upgrade.

For more information, refer note 2451049

4. Message Toast Support

In SP20 , a new scripting API command has been introduced for displaying non-interactive popup messages in SAP GUI for HTML similar to the "toast message" in SAPUI5.  Scripting API command was available only in slipstream engine with SP19. With this new command, you can now easily implement message toasts for simple scenarios, allowing for streamlined feedback that aligns with SAP Fiori standards. This addition helps enhance user experience by providing subtle, non-disruptive messages in SAP Screen Personas.

Example:  session.utils.showMessageToast("This is a toast message");

How it works

  • Shows a small popup message that disappears after a few seconds.

  • The message stays visible if the user hovers or taps on it.

Conclusion

The SP20 release brings meaningful enhancements that streamline flavor management, improve BDT handling, and provide greater flexibility for device-specific adaptations. Whether you’re managing complex environments or designing mobile-friendly screens, these features help deliver a more efficient and tailored user experience.

SP20 related notes: : https://me.sap.com/notes/3672078 

 

Learn more about SAP Screen Personas
  • Online training. The best way to learn the basics about SAP Screen Personas (Adapt UI for classic applications) is to take our free training course on the learning.sap.com platform: https://learning.sap.com/courses/adapting-the-ui-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-using-sap-screen-personas
  • Connect with your peers. Every other month, we have a group of customers that gather online to share best practices, demo their flavors, and answer each other’s questions. Experts from the product team also join to explain how to use the latest functionality. If you are interested in joining, you can sign up online to join the SAP Screen Personas practitioner forum. This will add you to the mailing list for the monthly meeting summaries. Please contact “Peter Spielvogel“ or me directly if you want to join the monthly calls.
  • Product documentation. The SAP Screen Personas documentation, provides more clear , comprehensive and the latest information about the product.

Going forward with SAP Screen Personas

  1. If you are on SP18 or earlier, we recommend you upgrade now, ideally going directly to SP20.
  2. If you are not currently using SAP Screen Personas, why not?
    Worried that we won’t support it into the future? Don’t be.      We are supporting SAP Screen Personas functionality through at least 2040.
    Have other concerns about the     roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post.the ability to adapt the UI of classic apps is something important to us.
    Have other concerns about the     roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post.
  3. SAP Screen Personas is now available with the Default Installation Stack of SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition

entry.title: IFRS 18 Explained: What SAP S/4HANA Customers Need to Know Before 2027
entry.content:
Spoiler
 

IFRS 18 introduces one of the biggest changes to financial statement presentation in decades, replacing IAS 1 and redefining how companies structure their Profit and Loss statements. This blog breaks down the new categories, required subtotals, MPM rules, and cash-flow changes in simple, human language — and explains how SAP is preparing to support customers across S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, and On-Premise. With comparative reporting for 2026 and mandatory adoption from 2027, now is the time for finance and IT teams to understand what’s coming and how to prepare their SAP landscape.

What Is IFRS 18 and Why Is It Important?

IFRS 18 is a brand-new reporting standard released by the IASB. It replaces IAS 1 (Presentation of Financial Statements) and becomes effective on January 1, 2027.

In simple terms, IFRS 18 changes how companies present their Income Statement (P&L) and how they explain their financial performance.

Think of it as a cleaner, more structured way to show:

  • Where money comes from
  • Where it goes
  • What part of the business truly drives performance

The goal is to:

  • Make financial statements easier to understand
  • Improve consistency across companies
  • Increase transparency for investors
  • Make comparison between companies more fair and simple

What’s Changing in the Profit and Loss Statement? 

IFRS 18 completely reorganizes the Profit and Loss (P&L) structure.
Instead of mixing items together, companies must now classify every income and expense into new categories:

New Mandatory Categories

  • Operating: Day-to-day business activities
  • Investing: Returns or costs related to long-term investments
  • Financing: Borrowings, interest, and funding-related items
  • Income Tax: All tax-related items
  • Discontinued Operations: Business operations that are shut down or sold

New Required Subtotals

Companies must show these subtotals:

  • Operating Profit
  • Profit or Loss Before Financing and Income Tax
  • Profit or Loss

This improves clarity and avoids situations where different companies calculate “operating profit” differently.

What Are Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs)?

IFRS 18 introduces strict rules for something many companies already do:
show custom KPIs like “Adjusted EBITDA,” “Core Profit,” or “Underlying Margin.”

These are called Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs).

Under IFRS 18, companies MUST:

  • Explain how the measure is calculated
  • Explain why it is useful
  • Provide a reconciliation to an official IFRS subtotal
  • Include this reconciliation in the notes, and it must be audited

This improves trust and transparency around custom metrics that companies use to tell their story.

Changes to the Cash Flow Statement

IFRS 18 also updates IAS 7 (Cash Flow Statements).
Previously, companies had flexibility in classifying certain cash flows.

Under IFRS 18:

  • Dividends paid → must be shown under Investing activities
  • Interest paid → must be shown under Financing activities
  • Interest received → must be shown under Investing activities

This eliminates the old “choice-based” method and brings global consistency.

Impact on Financial Reporting and Disclosure

IFRS 18 affects several areas of financial reporting:

P&L Structure

Companies must reorganize their charts of accounts and reporting hierarchies.

Disclosures and Notes

More detail is required, especially around MPMs, aggregation rules, and reconciliation.

Comparative Reporting

Mandatory disclosure of 2026 figures in the new IFRS 18 structure when reporting for 2027.

What Does This Mean for Companies Using SAP?

SAP is currently analysing the full impact of IFRS 18 and consulting with customers through Customer Engagement Initiatives.

Key areas SAP is reviewing include:

  • Functional areas
  • General Ledger structure
  • Valuation processes
  • Reporting frameworks in S/4HANA
  • Group Reporting layouts
  • Cash-flow classifications
  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA) extensibility

SAP expects to release a formal solution approach by December 2025(as documented in SAP Note-https://me.sap.com/notes/3670330/E) . This guidance is expected to be included in the IFRS 18 updates for SAP Group Reporting as part of the 1SG content package.

The solution may differ across editions:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    → Expect more standardized, pre-delivered content
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
    → More flexibility with governance
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
    → Potentially greater configurability

SAP will deliver updates through notes, documentation, and future releases.

How Customers Can Prepare Today

Even before SAP finalizes its solution, companies can begin preparing by:

✔ Reviewing current P&L structures
✔ Identifying where income/expense items will map under IFRS 18
✔ Understanding new disclosure requirements
✔ Reviewing cash-flow classifications
✔ Collecting internal MPM definitions
✔ Engaging with SAP through CEI or Customer Influence Requests

Early preparation will make the transition smoother when IFRS 18 becomes mandatory.

Conclusion

IFRS 18 represents a major shift in how companies communicate their financial performance. The new structure, required subtotals, stricter rules for custom KPIs, and updates to cash flow presentation will significantly impact both finance teams and system configurations.

As outlined in SAP Note 3670330, SAP is developing a comprehensive solution targeted for late 2025, with further updates expected as IFRS 18 continues to evolve. In my view, this is the right time for organizations to start understanding the new requirements, assess their current data and reporting structures, and begin preparing their SAP landscapes for a smooth transition.

More updates will come as SAP refines its roadmap — stay tuned.

entry.title: Re: Cost center determination logic in Price difference w...
entry.content:
Good day @yKim 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/9d949972f5924be792e8ad5b7871ddfb.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/adbae5bcd5994f159bf2847a11397b61/4d5e9cef91ef46ed8eb75c8d90f32e94.html?locale=en-US

Based on the information you provided, if you don’t maintain a default cost center or profit center in Manage Default Account Assignments for the price difference GL, then the system attempts to derive it from:

  • Order, Project, or CO assignment if these are available
  • Cost center on the PO or GR if it is available.

If none of those exist, it may fall back to default profit center, which is often derived from the user’s organisational data, cost center defaults or the company’s internal dummy profit center.

In your case, even though your screenshot shows you did not assign any default, the inventory line picks the profit center from the material master, while the price difference line (52041000) does not inherit it automatically. Since you did not assign a default account for the cost element, the system resolves the profit center using fallback logic suggesting that you either have a fallback rule or you have created an internal default.

My suggestion is to ensure consistent profit center assignment by using:

  • SSCUI 102639 to define a default profit center for the PRD cost element.
  • Substitution logic through implementing a BAdI if available in your system.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @weronika_niewiora661 
For the BDC assessment (AI role play) you will receive around 30 questions and the questions span all BDC topics that are covered in the learning journey "Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud".  The topics are pretty evenly weighted. When you begin the assessment you will see the scoring rubric which shows the topics that will come up and their respective weightings. Y can expect to have questions fired at you for around 20-25 minutes. When the assessment is over the AI will let you know and then you press the Save and View Analysis to get your score. If you passed - great! If you failed you will be able to read your detailed feedback which tells you where you were weak. If there is enough time left from the two hour allowance, you can have another go. The two hours is very generous and it means in theory you could have up to four attempts, with feedback provided to you after each attempt so you improve each time.

entry.title: Implications of Functional User license for Contingent workers when using onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss how a contingent worker is hired as an employee via SuccessFactors Onboarding and how this may affect the functional user license in SuccessFactors.

There are number of ways a user in SuccessFactors Employee Central can be a functional user:

  • They do not have access to SuccessFactors platform i.e. no login permissions in RBP.
  • They are seasonal worker with a length of service lest than 1 year.
  • Their details are mastered in an external HRIS.
  • They are contingent worker.

The full and functional user license only applies to SuccessFactors Employee Central.

A contingent worker will always be a functional user whether they have access to SuccessFactors platform or not.

In the scenario where you have a contingent worker who is ‘converting’ to an employee, this requires a termination and a hire record.  If you initiate onboarding for the contingent worker, they will complete their onboarding record for their new ‘employee’ record by switching the employment profile switcher.  Clearly for them to do this they will need access to SuccessFactors.  If they do not have access to SuccessFactors and access is given this WILL NOT switch them to a ‘full user license’ as they are a contingent worker, and all contingent workers are classified as functional users.
